newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thailand, Burma to build deep seaport.
newsitem.headline: Thailand, Burma to build deep seaport.

text.p: Thailand and Burma plan to jointly invest in a Burmese deep seaport that will link up with a major industrial estate now being studied, a senior official said on Tuesday.

Somchet Thinaphong, governor of the Industrial Estate Authority of Thailand (IEAT), told Reuters in an interview that his agency would join Italian-Thai Development Plc and Rangoon in building the Tavoy deep seaport in southern Burma. Tavoy is opposite the western Thai province of Kanchanaburi.
"IEAT is conducting a feasibility study with Italian-Thai Development and the study is expected to be completed in three months," Somchet said.
He declined to estimate the deep seaport's investment cost.
Italian-Thai is currently building a $149 million international airport at Mandalay, 560 kms (350 miles) north of Rangoon, that is due to be finished by 1999.

"The deep seaport will speed up movement of goods between the two countries and help Thailand save transportation fuel as there would be no need for ships to make de-tour trips via Singapore," said Italian-Thai's vice president Chatichai Chutima.
The Tavoy port project is part of a package to develop the Thai provinces of Chumphon, Prachuap Khiri Khan, Phetchaburi, Ratchaburi, Kanchanaburi and Samut Songkram.

The six provinces are covered by the Western Seaboard Development Project, in which a deep seaport has been operational in Prachuap Khiri Khan and downstream petrochemical plants and infrastructure are to be built, Somchet said.
Somchet said the plan for developing the provinces was modelled after Thailand's eastern and southern seaboard projects.
"The area will provide a big opportunity for investors," he said.
